description:
Klebsormidium nitens is a species of green algae that belongs to the class Klebsormidiophyceae. It is a filamentous, unbranched alga that is commonly found in terrestrial and freshwater environments, such as soil, rock surfaces, and damp habitats.

The cells of K. nitens are cylindrical, typically measuring between 5-15 μm in diameter and 10-50 μm in length. The cell walls are thin and the cells contain a single, parietal chloroplast that occupies a large portion of the cell volume. The chloroplast is typically cup-shaped and contains a single, distinct pyrenoid.

Reproduction in K. nitens occurs asexually through the formation of aplanospores, which are non-motile, thick-walled resting cells that can withstand adverse environmental conditions. Under favorable conditions, the aplanospores can germinate and give rise to new filaments.

K. nitens is known for its ability to tolerate a wide range of environmental stresses, such as desiccation, high light intensity, and extreme temperatures. This adaptability allows it to thrive in diverse terrestrial habitats, where it plays a role in soil stabilization and nutrient cycling.
